results.content:
Yes, great course so far; well presented and well thought out sequence.  Not sure how much I'll retain by the end since we've done many things more than one way, and since I couldn't do all of this in one session (more like one or two videos a day, which gives the brain more time to forget what came earlier, and that leads to re-visiting videos to refresh memory).  I understand why we redid things different ways, and appreciate it, just not sure how much I'll recall. Two other comments: 
1. the time estimates are a little short since it takes me longer to type the unfamiliar code than it does for Brad, and to correct spelling/typo mistakes etc. 
2. Maybe we'll get into this later on, but some pointers on figuring out why something isn't compiling would be much appreciated (rather than comparing my files with the posted zip files :)! )
Thanks for the opportunity to provide feedback!

results.content:
This is not my first course of Brad that I took. (for his other courses I gave 5 stars).

Advantages:
+ Brad is one of the best and clearest instuctores in Udemy. 
+ The course deals with up-to-date react tools like context, immer, lazy-loading, etc...
+ The project is a good exercise for the "real-wrold" work, and can be a a nice referance.

DisAdvantages:
- A lot of repetitive code ! (for example all the "useEffect()" copy paste). This is make the code less readable, maintained and reusable. I think that Brad should combine proper code writing habits in this course (like he did in his previous courses). 

- This is true that 'hooks' changed react-dvelopers lives, but I think that new react developer should be familiar also with class components.

- I think that Brad should combine some jss tool in the course to show the combintaion between react and css. 

In the bottom line, I think that this course is very good as a 'complementary metrial' to other React courses, but not for first course.

Nice course! Every React course leaves me feeling like I've learned more but know less, and this course is no different. I guess that's one of the reasons why coding is so rewarding. Every JS library, framework and compiler I study opens my mind to even more possibilities.

The instructor is very good, the videos are well shot, and the course is paced well. About halfway through it became more of a code-along for me, but it was still very educational.

What I found especially helpful was the use of an Express.js server specifically developed for this course (source code provided), as opposed to just using public APIs.

I'll definitely take more of Brad's courses.

results.content:
Great course!

I liked that the lessons strictly focused on React:
- you're not wasting time coding HTML and CSS,
- you're no wasting time configuring development tools,
- the project uses very few external libraries. It's mainly React functionalities.
The promise is to learn React, and as you concentrate on it, you understand it deeply and quickly.

The course is also clean and well prepared.
You follow an exercise from start to end. I appreciated having had an example of an entire project. 
You're not just watching someone commenting on his work, neither. The author designed his course. Each step in the construction of the application presents a new functionality of the framework.

In my opinion, there might have just one black spot in this course (which might also be a good point for others): the author assumes that you don't know anything. That means that he explains and describes everything: no omissions, no ellipses. It's nice because you're never lost this way, but at a point, you start to find the lessons verbose and slow (boring?).

To conclude, the course promises to teach React, and it does. No more, no less. I now feel like I understand the library. I'm going to check it by coding a new project tomorrow :-)
results.content_html:
Great course!

I liked that the lessons strictly focused on React:
- you're not wasting time coding HTML and CSS,
- you're no wasting time configuring development tools,
- the project uses very few external libraries. It's mainly React functionalities.
The promise is to learn React, and as you concentrate on it, you understand it deeply and quickly.

The course is also clean and well prepared.
You follow an exercise from start to end. I appreciated having had an example of an entire project.
You're not just watching someone commenting on his work, neither. The author designed his course. Each step in the construction of the application presents a new functionality of the framework.

In my opinion, there might have just one black spot in this course (which might also be a good point for others): the author assumes that you don't know anything. That means that he explains and describes everything: no omissions, no ellipses. It's nice because you're never lost this way, but at a point, you start to find the lessons verbose and slow (boring?).

To conclude, the course promises to teach React, and it does. No more, no less. I now feel like I understand the library. I'm going to check it by coding a new project tomorrow :-)

results.content:
This is an amazing course to start learning React. Brad started a real strong introduction as to what problems React is solving. Step by step, he was able to build on the concepts of what React is. It is mostly a demonstration and a code-along course that shows his workaround and logic. 
The good things I grasped:
- the use of Immer, useReducer, useContext, his use of "dispatch" method
- use of switch statements
- deploying the frontend and backend successfully
- creating a react app from scratch 
- all the necessary files for comparing 
- the videos are enough to keep attention span going
- the files are up-to-date

Some things to add
- please include tips on organizing components for best practice, the components folder is full of js files
- a lot of copy and pasting but nothing can be done there I guess (most steps are repetitive)
- I noticed that Brad only replies to some questions, there are some questions that need to be filtered but there are some questions worth replying to but left unanswered.

results.content: As of the first half of 2020, it's a great lecture to learn the latest React basics. The English pronunciation of the instructor is correct and the progress is a bit slow, but it is suitable for beginners. In particular, other popular React courses (in Udemy) are based on previous React versions, so they do not provide you with the strengths and uses of the recent React. Use only the Class components to change the State or... Just like it doesn't show you how to use Hook properly. If you want to learn based on the most up-to-date reacts, this lecture is the ideal choice.

results.content:
Excellent course. Especially for the very newest in React which is fat becoming industry standard.

The good:
-Brad is a very relaxed and excellent teacher.
-The content is up to date and very applicable to the real world.
-Explanations are clear and easy (as easy as react gets anyway) to understand.
-You will build and deploy an actual real world app. An awesome one.

The bad:
-The Q&A section doesn't get enough attention. There are valid unanswered questions that are months old.
-There's a lot of "copy and paste, --> reuse and change the code to save time" within the course. Copying code and changing it up sure does save time, but you lose the learning opportunity that comes from repeating a task. 
-This point might not necessarily be "bad", but I would say that you should do a JS preferably modern/ES6 before taking on this course. There's lots of JS concepts and methods which will be very hard to grasp with no prior JS knowledge. Also having a good understanding of HTML is important. Finally, I would say to truly appreciate the course, some CSS knowledge is vital. 

If you're struggling to decide on a React course on Udemy, look no further. This once is definitely the best I've done.

results.content:
This is not my first React online course but it's definitely the best one. 
It covers everything you need to know to start working with React and it's focused on React Hooks and functional components not on class components which in my opinion is much clearer approach than managing state in class component with Redux for example.
The only reason I'm giving 4.5 stars not 5 is because, the project we worked on could be set up with react create instead of with manual Webpack configuration. That's what I've done and it worked perfectly, without any single issue during deployment process. But that is obviously how I prefer, otherwise it's 5/5.

results.content:
Ich bin total begeistert von dem Kurs. Brad spricht gut zu verstehendes Englisch, ich habe alles zu 100% verstanden sowohl akustisch als auch Inhaltlich. Ab und zu gibt es ein paar „Okey‘s“ Füllworte zu viel, aber es ist zu vernachlässigen und stört nicht zu sehr.
Die Themen sind gut aufeinander aufgebaut und ich finde es auch gut wie Brad einen mitnimmt ein Problem auf unterschiedliche Arten zu lösen. Beispiel status, Reducer, Immer... man lernt die unterschiedlichen Möglichkeiten wie dieses genutzt werden kann.

Sehr gut fand ich auch die socket Technik für den Chat, es ging weit über „einfach nur React“ hinaus.

Was mir auch sehr gefallen hat, war die „einfache“ Einleitung in der ersten Lektion, wo Brad auf einfache Art gezeigt hat, was React ausmacht.

Der Kurs ist wirklich sehr gut gelungen und ich habe mir darauf hin 3 weitere Kurse von Brad vorgemerkt (da sie auch gerade im Angebot waren), die ich auch gucken werde.

Danke für diesen wirklich schönen Kurs, Alex

################


I am totally excited about the course. Brad speaks English that can be well understood by a non native „listener“ , I understand everything 100% even though my English is not good. For German ears every now and then there are a few "Okey" filler words too much, but it is negligible.
The topics are well structured and I think it's good how Brad takes you with him his way to solve a problem in different ways. Example status, reducer, Immer ... you learn the different possibilities and how to use them.

I liked the socket technology for the chat very much, too - it went far beyond "just React".

What I also really liked was the “simple” introduction in the first lesson, where Brad showed what React is all about.

The course was really very good and I subscribed three more courses from Brad (since they were also on offer) and look forward to watch them.

Thanks for this really nice course, Alex

results.content:
Honestly, this course is not much more than coding along with an instructor for hours on end. After a great start where Brad competently explains what React is and, more importantly, why you should use it, the course quickly drifts off into a "just type along with me" style and becomes increasingly mundane. There is not a lot to be gained from a course structure like this, in my opinion. Anyone can feel like a competent developer after coding along with someone else, but this will not prepare you for any real coding work where you have to do it all by yourself.

Although Brad is great at explaining code concepts, at some point it seems like he just doesn't want to bother anymore. For example, not being able to use async with useEffect. Well, why then? Just take a minute to explain why this is the case or at least provide some documentation. Hoping to get some answers in the Q&A? Well, support is pretty much nonexistent so good luck with finding any answers to your questions. I feel like this is something a Udemy instructor should spend a lot of time on: providing answers for people who are stuck after purchasing your course.

To me this feels like a missed opportunity for Brad. He definitely knows how to explain complex concepts in a way that even my grandmother could understand, which is quite an impressive skill to have. But after a few hours of "just copy this file from GitHub and code by watching me do it", it gets so dull that I could not find the energy to continue and complete the course.

To be fair, I did gain some knowledge from this course. Composition never really clicked until now and Immer is a pretty cool tool. But, there were also moments where Brad deliberately opted for an out-of-date solution (using HOCs with React Router instead of their Hooks).

If you're a complete beginner I would say watch the first couple of sections of this course to get a grasp on React and then do Andrew Mead's course. Unless you enjoy just typing along with someone else, I would not necessarily recommend this course.

If you are new to React or been at it for a short while, this course unlocks your developer superpowers!

results.content: This is a top-notch course for learning modern React.  The project, a chat blog, is the real jewel of this course.  You build it with React and connect to a real database.  Along the way, the instructor dives deep into the front-end explanation, and he provides just enough back-end instruction for you to comfortably interface your React app with Node.js and MongoDB.  This course is not an easy one, but it is an excellent choice for those who want to broaden their JavaScript skills and learn how to build full-featured sites and applications using React.  Brad’s approach to teaching is to the point; he does not waste time on superfluous chat or instruction.  His React course clocks in at just under 16 hours in length, but each minute of instruction is spot on with high educational value and clear direction.  Thus, do not be fooled by the relatively short length of his course.  It is power packed with tons of valuable information for inspiring React developers.  Before I took Brad’s course, I knew little to nothing about React.  Now, I have the confidence and the skill to build full React applications using a wide cross-section of custom and third-party components and tools.

results.content:
My team and I did setup a production project based on this course, its sibling "GIT a webdev job" and everything went fine.

Howerver we got an external consultancy to appraise our progress and they said, they have never seen anyone configuring webpack on their own without create-react-app. They claim it is an absolute industry standard andit should be used and ejecting should be avoided. Another comment we got, was that a complex app like ours (and it does not seem overly complex to me) should not go without Redux. We did follow Brad by using useImmer

The necessary refactoring is a step that can not be avoided when starting with an inexperienced team, so no harm done, I just wanted to share this experience.

I know from the q&a that Brad insists he wants to teach people what is happening behind the scenes and I do agree. It feels good to know, how things are working "behind the scenes" However I think he should also have explained the cra option and if it is such a standard, one should stick to this. Also using cra is a great way to set up simple projects to play around with.

As I still liked the course, and nowadays anything below 4 stars is regarded as a failure, I will stick with the original assesment (5 Stars), but I wanted to share my experience
